Implementing Power Suspend/Resume Functionality

Send comments on this topic.
Some types of flash and/or flash controller hardware requires special handling when dealing with power suspend/resume operations, because they do not preserve the hardware state across a suspend/resume operation. Therefore when power is resumed, the hardware state may have changed, and any pending or subsequent operations may fail.

The FlashFX power suspend/resume features are are controlled by the FFXCONF_POWERSUSPENDRESUME preprocessor setting. This is currently defined at the OS level, in oesl.h. As FlashFX is shipped, this is set to TRUE only for those operating systems which support it. To add FlashFX driver support for this feature to a FlashFX block device driver for an OS which does not already support the feature, set FFXCONF_POWERSUSPENDRESUME to TRUE, and see the following instructions.

If FFXCONF_POWERSUSPENDRESUME is TRUE, FlashFX includes support for power suspend and resume functionality in the call stack. This must be combined with special logic at the FIM or NTM level, as well as in the OS-specific block device driver code.

At the low level, the FIM/NTM's IORequest function must be updated (if necessary) to support the FXIOFUNC_FIM_POWER_SUSPEND and FXIOFUNC_FIM_POWER_RESUME I/O control functions. In many cases, these modifications will be OEM hardware specific, and therefore this functionality is implemented in a stubbed fashion in most FIMs and NTMs. However, the PXA320 NTM, implemented in ntpxa320.c, is an example of an NTM where this has already been done.

At the high level, the OS-specific block device driver must be modified (if necessary) to issue the proper "suspend" and "resume" requests when notified by the operating system. At "suspend" time, the function FfxDriverDiskPowerSuspend() must be called, and at "resume" time, the function FfxDriverDiskPowerResume() must be called. The OS must provide this notification ONLY after it has ceased to issue I/O requests to the block device instance.

Note -- It is critical that FfxDriverDiskPowerSuspend() be called once for each Disk in the system. For example, if there are three Disks all mapped to DEV0, the actual request to suspend will only be passed down the call stack to the FIM/NTM, once all three Disks have received their suspend requests.
